entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Kissed kĭst;p. pr. & vb. n. Kissing
entry.ety: OE. kissen cussen, AS. cyssan, fr. coss a kiss; of uncertain origin; akin to D. kus, G. kuss, Icel. koss

sn.def: To salute with the lips, as a mark of affection, reverence, submission, forgiveness, etc.
sn.q: He . . . kissed her lips with such a clamorous smack, That at the parting all the church echoed.

sn.def: To touch gently, as if fondly or caressingly.
sn.q: When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees.

cs.cd: a perfumed sugarplum to sweeten the breath.

sn.def: To make or give salutation with the lips in token of love, respect, etc.; as, kiss and make friends.
To meet; to come in contact; to touch fondly.
sn.q: Like fire and powder, Which as they kiss consume.
Rose, rose and clematis, Trail and twine and clasp and kiss.

entry.ety: OE. kiss, derived under the influence of the verb from the older form coss, AS. coss. See Kiss v.

sn.def: A salutation with the lips, as a token of affection, respect, etc.; as, a parting kiss; a kiss of reconciliation.
sn.q: Last with a kiss, she took a long farewell.
Dear as remembered kisses after death.
